docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Mail steamship Arctic, from Liverpool about 11 1/2 o'clock M. A. Wednesday, September 7, arrived here yesterday morning. The Africa arrived Sunday, 4th inst., at "Bell Buoy," off Liverpool, 4 o'clock, morning.
docs.snippet: The U.S. Mail steamship Arctic, from Liverpool about 11 1/2 o'clock M. A. Wednesday, September 7, arrived here yesterday morning. The Africa arrived Sunday, 4th inst., at "Bell Buoy," off Liverpool, 4 o'clock, morning.

headline.main: THE CASE OF MRS. NORTON.; Interesting Letter in Reply to her Husband.

docs.lead_paragraph: From the London News. The mail brings no news of any abatement of the terrible fever at New Orleans. The deaths are still told in hundreds. There is in existence, and in England, a pamphlet written by a physician to prove that New-Orleans is the most healthy city in the United States.

headline.main: The Yellow Fever at New-Orleans and Mobile--The Recent Duel at Charleston.

docs.lead_paragraph: New-Orleans papers of the 11th inst., are received. The total number of deaths during the week ending on the 10th inst., was 576, including 421 by the yellow fever. The total number of deaths since the commencement of the epidemic, had been 7,700 by yellow fever, and by other diseases 2,400.

headline.main: THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD.; The Improvements of Modern Travel.

docs.lead_paragraph: There is nothing, perhaps, in connection with modern improvements which would so astonish our grandfathers, if those worthy old persons were to come to life again, as the changes for the better in the way of locomotion.
docs.snippet: There is nothing, perhaps, in connection with modern improvements which would so astonish our grandfathers, if those worthy old persons were to come to life again, as the changes for the better in the way of locomotion.

docs.lead_paragraph: YELLOW FEVER AT MONTGOMERY, ALA-The Board of Health of Montgomery report that on the 12th August, two cases of yellow fever arrived in that city direct from New-Orleans. Since that day, 13 cases have occurred, nine of which came direct from New Orleans, Mobile and Pensacola The remaining four cases occurred in a family of Irish laborers. living near the river.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE FEVER IN MOBILE.--The Mobile papers contain a list of interments for five days, ending Sept. 8. from which it appears that there were 130 of yellow fever, and 15 other diseases-total 145. This does not include the interments in the Roman Catholic Cemetery.

docs.lead_paragraph: We have received dates from Galveston to the 28 inst , and Indianola to the 30th ult. The yellow fever has made its appearance in Galveston, as the following resolution, published by the Board of Health on the 28 inst., will show;
